description.p: The organization that prepared this SSP. If developed in-house, this is the CSP itself.
The organization that prepared this SAR.
The organization for which this SAR was prepared. Typically the CSP.
The individual or individuals accountable for the accuracy of this SAR.
The organization performing the assessment.
The individual or individuals performing the assessment.
The individual leading the assessment activities.
The individual or individuals performing the penetration test.
The individual leading the penetration test activities.
The management-level POC within the assessor's organization accountable for the organization's assessment performance.
At least three CSP testing points of contact must be identified in a FedRAMP SAP.
An operations center role, such as a SOC or NOC.

role.title: CSP's End of Testing Notification POC

description.p: A role for an individual within the CSP to be notified by the assessor when testing is complete.
A role for the individuals within the CSP who are to receive the assessment results.

remarks.p: The assessor's HQ, or the address of the assessment team's primary business location.
Replace sample 3PAO information.
If the assessor is A2LA Certified, include the ISO/IEC-17020

party.name: Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program: Program Management Office

remarks.p: This party entry must be present in a FedRAMP SAR.
The uuid may be different; however, the uuid must be associated with the "fedramp-pmo" role in the responsible-party assemblies.
Exactly one party
This is the assessor.
Exactly one party.
This is the UUID for the CSP in the SSP.
If no OSCAL-based SSP exists, create a CSP party in the SAP, and provide that UUID here.
One ore more parties
Exactly one party
Assessment Organization (3PAO)
One or more parties
Exactly one party
One or more partys
Exactly one party
Exactly one party
Exactly one party
The party-uuid should reference a party in the SSP.
If an appropriate party does not exist in the SSP, the SAP tool should add a party to the SAP, or have the CSP add the party to the SSP..
The SAP tool should not modify the SSP.
There should be at least three CSP Assessment POCs.
At least one should be available 24x7 during assessment activities.
At least one should be an operations center, such a SOC or NOC.
The party-uuid should reference a party in the SSP or SAP.
If an appropriate party does not exist in the SSP or SAP, the SAR tool should add a party to the SAR.
The SAP tool should not modify the SSP.
One or more parties
One or more parties
This OSCAL-based FedRAMP SAR Template can be used for the FedRAMP initial or annual assessment reporting.
FedRAMP prefers the path for the SAP be relative to the location of this SAR file. Absolute links will not work when FedRAMP tools import the content.
This may point to a back-matter resource using a URI fragment.

description.p: This describes an activity that was not defined in the SAP, but was performed during the assessment.
Describe test step #1
Describe test step #2
Describe test step #3
Brief assessment description.
A Windows laptop, which is not defined in the SSP inventory.
Describe assessment laptop.

remarks.p: Ideally, this assessment laptop would have been defined in the SAP, and not repeated here.
If the laptop was not known at the time the SAP was drafted, or something different was used, it must be defined here.
Cites the Assessment laptop above.
Cites the Vulnerability Scanning Tool identified in the SAP.
Cites the XYZ Database Scanning Tool identified in the SAP.
This is an example of a revised assessment platform.
Ideally, all assessment platforms and components are defined in the SAP. If there is a departure from what is defined in the SAP, it must be defined in the SAR.
This is a mixed example showing a revised component (a different assessment laptop defined as a component in the SAR) being paired with tools previously defined in the SAP.

description.p: Include all controls in the specified in the assessment plan, except as explicitly excluded here.

part.name: authorization-statement
part.p: Priority levels were established based on [describe].

part.name: authorization-statement
part.p: Notes and other information the assessor may wish to provide related to a continued authorization recommendation.

part.name: authorization-statement
part.p: [3PAO Name] attests that the SAR from the [system name] [initial | annual] assessment testing provides a complete assessment of the applicable FedRAMP controls as stipulated in the SAP. Evidence to validate the successful implementation of the various security controls has been collected and validated. Based on the remaining risks, and continuous improvements of security related processes and controls, [3PAO Name] recommends a continued authorization be granted for the [system name].

entry.title: Send Final Version of SAR to CSP and ISSO

description.p: optional description here
[EXAMPLE]The AC policy existed, and had all the required elements.

remarks.p: If the policy is defined in the SSP as a component, you can cite it using subject, and use the UUID of the policy component in the SSP.

description.p: Reviewed Policy

remarks.p: If the policy is not an SSP component, it should be attached to the SAR as a resource, and cited here as a URI fragment.
The subject-reference identifies a policy that was reviewed and is attached in the back-matter.
The observation source is linked to the task in the schedule associated with performing document reviews.
Even though the policy may be defined in the SSP and OSCAL would allow the SAR to reference it, FedRAMP requires the assessor attach all evidence to the SAR..

description.p: [EXAMPLE]The person interviewed knew about the policy and where to find it.
This describes the evidence, and adds relevant detail.
For example, this could cite where to find this information in interview notes.

remarks.p: The subject-reference is linked to the person interviewed.
The observation source is linked to the task in the schedule associated with performing staff interviews.
The relevant-evidence is linked to the interview notes.
These may be defined in the SSP, SAP, or SAR. Tools should check all three locations.

description.p: Undocumented devices found on network.
Raw scanner tool output - discovery scan.

remarks.p: Undocumented hosts are entered into the SAR's result/local-definitions section as inventory-items or components.
Undocumented hosts are listed in the observations assembly as subject-references.
The origin must contain the UUID of the tool used to perform the scan.

description.p: [EXAMPLE]Scanner Output.
Raw scanner tool output - Infrastructure and OS Scan.
Provide the justification for the operational requirement.
A screen shot showing the system impact when patch is applied.
Vendor detail describing why this happens.
Describe the false positive here.
A screen shot showing the setting is correct
Vendor detail describing why this happens.
Describe the risk adjustment justification here.
Describe the risk adjustment evidence here.

remarks.p: Attach relevant evidence as a resource.
Use a link field with a URI fragment to link to the resource using its UUID.

description.p: [EXAMPLE]Spear phishing test yielded a 22% click rate.
[EXAMPLE]The target threshold was below 20%.
Spear Phishing Report.
[EXAMPLE]Describe the finding.
Penetration Test Report.
The policy describes a procedure, which could not be found.

remarks.p: The type field designates this observations as an issue with a statement in the SSP. Tools can filter on this field to summarize all SSP issues.
The origin identifies the assessor who found the SSP statement issue.
If relevant, evidence can be cited as well using the relevant-evidence assembly, such as a screenshot showing a setting is different than stated in the SSP.

description.p: This is a description of the identified risk.
TCW: Identified Risk.
Scans: Vulnerability Description.
Pen Test: Risk Description.
RET: Description.

statement.p: This is a statement about the identified risk.

description.p: A description of the recommended remediation.
TCW: Assessor's recommended remediation (lifecycle="recommendation").
Scans: Tool's recommended remediation (lifecycle="recommendation")
Pen Test: Assessor's recommended remediation (lifecycle="recommendation")
RET: Assessor's recommended remediation (lifecycle="recommendation").
POA&M: CSP's intended remediation (no type flag).
This is a description of the identified risk.
TCW: Identified Risk.
Scans: Vulnerability Description.
Pen Test: Risk Description.
RET: Description.

statement.p: This is a statement about the identified risk.

description.p: A description of the recommended remediation.
TCW: Assessor's recommended remediation (lifecycle="recommendation").
Scans: Tool's recommended remediation (lifecycle="recommendation")
Pen Test: Assessor's recommended remediation (lifecycle="recommendation")
RET: Assessor's recommended remediation (lifecycle="recommendation").
POA&M: CSP's intended remediation (no type flag).
This is a description of the vulnerability provided by the tool.

statement.p: This is a statement about the identified risk as provided by the tool.
This field must be present, but may be blank (or state 'No Risk Statement' if no statement is provided by the tool.

description.p: Describe mitigating factor
Describe why the cited implementation statement justifies lowering the risk.
A description of the recommended remediation as provided by the tool.

remarks.p: Recommended and planned remediation entries should remain when the risk is closed.
Simply add the closure-actions field and change the risk-status to "closed".

description.p: A description of the recommended remediation as provided by the assessor.

remarks.p: The assessor may add their recommendation in addition to the tool's recommendation, or if no tool recommendation is provided.
The assessor should leave the tool recommendation, even if adding their own.
Recommended and planned remediation entries should remain when the risk is closed.
Simply add the closure-actions field and change the risk-status to "closed".

description.p: Describe what action(s) the CSP took to close the risk.
[EXAMPLE]Applied patch. Vulnerability no longer found in subsequent scan.
This is a description of the issue found by the penetration testing team.

statement.p: This is a statement about the risk identified by penetration testing.

description.p: A description of the recommended remediation as provided by the assessor.

remarks.p: The assessor may add their recommendation.

description.p: An overall statement about the system's satisfaction of this objective.

remarks.p: There should be at least one related-observation for each test method. There may be more than one.
This objective only has one method (Examine), so there should be at least one related-objservation.

description.p: An overall statement about the system's satisfaction of this objective.

remarks.p: There should be at least one related-observation for each test method. There may be more than one.
This objective only has one method (Examine), so there should be at least one related-objservation.

description.p: An overall statement about the system's satisfaction of this objective.

remarks.p: There should be at least one related-observation for each test method. There may be more than one.
This objective has two methods (Examine and Interview), so there should be at least two related-objservation, including at least one observaton of each type.

description.p: [EXAMPLE]There is an issue with an SSP Statement.

remarks.p: The implementation-statement-uuid contains the UUID of the erroneous statement in the SSP.
The related-observation contains the UUID of an observation with details about the issue, including a statement and any relevant evidence.

description.p: The results of the discovery scan.

remarks.p: The UUID for the tool operator must be listed as the party-uuid for the finding. There may be more than one.

description.p: An example set of infrastructure scan findings.
The Results of the spear phishing test.

remarks.p: When reporting a result for a test such as the spear phishing activity, a risk assembly is required if the result is to be reported in the Risk Exposure Table.

description.p: A finding from penetration testing activities.

remarks.p: If a penetration test result is favorable, such as to say the SOC detected the activities appropriately, no risk is required.
If a penetration test result identifies a vulnerability or deficiency, the risk assembly is required.
Other controls omitted from example.
Other controls omitted from example.

description.p: [EXAMPLE]This is the contents of the Observations and Evidence cell in the TCW.

remarks.p: A tool could use either an rlink or base64 field.
If both are present, FedRAMP tools will give preference to the base64 content.
There may be more than one rlink.
If there is no base64 field, at lest one of the rlink fields must include a relative path.

description.p: Signed SAR

remarks.p: FedRAMP is formulating guidelines for handling digital/electronic signatures in OSCAL, and welcome feedback on solutions.
For now, FedRAMP recommends one of the following:

ul.li: Render the OSCAL SAR content as a PDF that is digitally signed and attached.
Render the OSCAL SAR content as printed pages that are physically signed, scanned, and attached.

remarks.p: If your organization prefers another approach, please seek prior approval from the FedRAMP PMO.
Must be present in a FedRAMP SSP.
Must be present in a FedRAMP SSP.

description.p: FedRAMP Logo

remarks.p: Must be present in a FedRAMP SSP.
